Transcription for 557345

Yn ymwneud, 16 o'r 9, Simon Rhys Phillips yn gweithredwr ar y prosiect C.Empres.
Rwy'n ymwneud â Tim Deer Jones, felly rydym yn siarad am y cyfleoedd o'r cyfleoedd yno.
Yn gyfleoedd, dim ond, a oes gennych chi'n fwyaf am eich hun, a chi ydych chi, a'r hyn a'r hyn.
Yn ymwneud â'r cyfleoedd C.Empres, fe wnaethon ni gweithio fel gweithredwr ar y cyfleoedd yno,
a chyflwyno yn St.Florans, sy'n ddaeth yn ymwneud â 10B, a mewn cyfleoedd yno,
a chyflwyno ar y cyfleoedd yno.
Fe wnaethon ni gweithio gyda Friends of the Earth Cymru i gweithio fel gweithredwr ac ymwneudwr ar y cyfleoedd
yn y cyfleoedd yno yn ystod y cyfleoedd yno a'r cyfleoedd yno.

I mean,
about

and as I say I would
posit that I may have had

and

of seeing all that wildlife

and then there's the physical effects
and I didn't work on clean-up

and certainly
speaking about

and having observed, oh well actually

who fell into their fights largely
on the distress and the

and who couldn't fish and all that sort of stuff.
And then the long-term health effects
and speaking to people,
I have spoken to people
who lived by the beach
and whose children became out of the blue,
had terrible, terrible chest problems
and were diagnosed as asthmatic
during this period of time when
you could smell oil everywhere even in land
and during the period of time when

but during periods of relatively strong wind
when oil was being blown ashore
actually in sea spray
and marine aerosols and dispersants were being
blown ashore as well, well I have spoken to people
whose children had sort of out of the blue
and as a father myself
and an asthmatic

terrible shock
and a sort of huge worry for the parents concerned.
And then I have spoken to other people
who feel that their rare blood cancers
that they have developed
post the sea empress were perhaps something to do with breathing in
again the fumes, I have spoken to people who
were very good surfers
before the sea empress and got themselves work on the clean up

ability to stand up and their sense of balance went
and a load of neurological symptoms
slowly crept upon them
and one chap, this is only me saying this

but one chap I have spoken to
used to win the occasional prize at surfing competitions
and now can't even stand up on a board
because his sense of balance has gone and his legs are weak
and his neurological co-ordination has fallen to pieces.
Well who knows whether that's to do with the spill
but there are people here who see that these things happened
following their involvement with the spill
and therefore feel that maybe the spill damaged them
and without the follow up, adequate scientific follow up
which I think should have been put in place
and ought to be put in place in future spills

because those are the guys who really know what the community

they will have personal knowledge of what happens
in the community who's ill, who isn't ill
whose life has fallen to pieces
who's had a nervous breakdown because of the stresses of the oil spill
whereas at county county level you're dealing with
people who no matter how good their intentions are
they're also managing the county county budget
and in Pembrokeshire of course the county council earns quite a lot of money
from remittances from the oil companies
and the Milford Haven Port Authority
so you can't really think of the local authority
at that level as being
without constraint
when it makes its decisions because it has to balance a lot of
different competing interests
whereas perhaps your parish councillor might be
in a very basic position where he can very adequately
represent what the people in his parish want
in terms of long term research and stuff
and there's a much encouraged attitude
you find also
you see it in Pembrokeshire, oh what are we talking about that for now
that's over and gone with, let's put it behind us and not talk about it
and that's partly to do with the fears
of ongoing financial impacts on local businesses
oh we don't want to stir all that up again
because it was bad enough for the first two or three years after the spill
when you couldn't get people down here to do bees and bees
people didn't want to come for holidays and all that sort of stuff
so there's that
and then people, I don't think, a lot of people
don't want to revisit the trauma
so thumbs up and
congratulations to the people who have come and spoken to this project
because in many ways
they've actually bucked the trend
here of people wishing to not
revisit a very very unpleasant experience
I think that's one of the things we've been asking really
is how, it's 20 years now, it's how
I think a lot of people are still kind of pretty saved into their brains really
I would say, it strikes me, don't put moods in your mouth
but that would strike me that it could be yesterday
for a lot of people, would that be the case for you?
oh yes yes, I mean in the course of preparing myself
for this contribution
Vox Pop, verbal contribution to yourselves
and also the recent work that I've been doing
as I said earlier on oil smells in the Arctic
I was
interested to dig out my photographic archive
of the various oil spills that I've looked at
and I, you know, not ashamed to admit
that there were photographs there that I had taken
that brought it all back so much
you know, that I did feel very sad
and quite tearful
a particular photograph of a
I took a sequence of photographs of a guillemot
struggling to come ashore
you see, the emotional impact now is hitting me
struggling to come ashore through really thick oil on Manabea beach
and he got so far up
and you had this
there was a big southwesterly wind blowing at the time
there was a big surf breaking at Manabea
so you had all this chocolate mousse emulsion
which is pretty much like
yeah, like chocolate sauce
and this poor bird was
you could see him stick his head up above it
and get up and then he got to the soap
where on a normal day the wave would break
and then it would recede and you'd have a big area of foam left
but it would only be a couple
he got to that stage and he was so overloaded with oil
that he was trying to stagger up the beach
and then another wave would come and hit him
and he would be gone
and you'd see him rolling around in the backwash
all upside down
it was just a terrible, terrible, terrible thing to watch
and I had a sequence of about five or six photographs of him
and as I remember it
there were people from RSPCA on the beach
trying to rescue live birds
but they couldn't get him
and he got so far up the beach
and then maybe the ninth or the seventh wave came
broke over him and took him away again
and he must have been amongst those
what we estimate to be in there were maybe 40,000 or 50,000 dead birds
across the whole area in that time
and well that was just a trauma
and seeing this sequence of photographs that I'd taken
just brought it all back
and it did, it made me feel really, really sad
and really, really stressed
and I had to put it all down and I couldn't look at those photographs
for two or three days although I was supposed to be sorting them out
to find examples to put into this report that I was writing
but I mean it really was emotionally very difficult
even at the 20 year remove
and I can understand
I'm just very gratified really
that you've had a good feedback here
because a lot of people that I speak to
they don't want to wake those memories up
they don't want to talk about what are you talking about that for they say
let's over and done with, leave it alone, let's forget it, let's move on
but for me it's very difficult to move on
because if it happened once it can happen again
the inadequacies that I see in some of the responses
make you fear for what happens next time
or not necessarily to us
but people are getting
being impacted by marine oil spills all the time
in a global sense
and things must be improved, we must try and work
to stop those accidents happening
and then if they do happen
we must look for the most efficient and effective
and ecologically safe ways of doing the clean up
and we must also be very well aware
of the fact of what is the impact
actually not on the finances
just the finances of those communities
but actually the long term emotional
mental, physical, psychological and societal health
of those communities
and while you can walk around and
well Pembrokeshire looks as if it's pretty much functioning
but there are people here who have been
one way or another severely affected by that spill
and although they are now getting on with life
and living with it, they are still carrying those scars
be they physical health, mental health, emotional health
or financial health, they are still carrying
those scars and the impacts of what they went through
for those two or three years while it was really bad here
